headline: Subdued decision in Google antitrust trial may help keep a monopoly in power
summary: After a five-year legal showdown pitting the U.S. Department of Justice against Google, a federal judge concluded that the disruptive forces of artificial intelligence technology will have a better chance of hobbling an illegal monopoly than any restraints imposed by a court order.  After ruling that Google's dominant search engine had turned into an illegal monopoly back in August 2024, the judge spent the next 13 months mulling the best way to rein in the technology powerhouse's bad behavior.

raw.headline: Subdued decision in Google antitrust trial may help keep a monopoly in power
raw.summary: After a five-year legal showdown pitting the U.S. Department of Justice against Google, a federal judge concluded that the disruptive forces of artificial intelligence technology will have a better chance of hobbling an illegal monopoly than any restraints imposed by a court order.  After ruling that Google's dominant search engine had turned into an illegal monopoly back in August 2024, the judge spent the next 13 months mulling the best way to rein in the technology powerhouse's bad behavior.

headline: Why Are Rivian (RIVN) Shares Soaring Today
summary: Shares of electric vehicle manufacturer Rivian (NASDAQ:RIVN) jumped 7.4% in the afternoon session after the company confirmed the upcoming integration of Apple CarKey support and as analysts anticipate strong demand for its R2 SUV. The Apple CarKey feature will allow owners to use their iPhones and Apple Watches as vehicle keys, enhancing user convenience. This news adds to the positive sentiment surrounding the electric vehicle maker's upcoming R2 SUV, for which analysts foresee strong demand.

headline: Alphabet Stock Hits an All-Time High. Google Avoided the Worst in its Antitrust Case.
summary: Shares of Google-parent  Alphabet  soared to new highs after the federal district court judge in the U.S. vs Google case released a seemingly limited set of remedies to mitigate the tech giant’s monopoly around internet search.  Among his rulings, U.S. District Judge Amit Mehta said on Tuesday that the search giant wouldn’t have to sell its Chrome web browser.  In a closely watched part of the case, Google also won’t be barred from paying Apple to make Google the default search provider on its devices.

raw.headline: Alphabet Stock Hits an All-Time High. Google Avoided the Worst in its Antitrust Case.
raw.summary: Shares of Google-parent  Alphabet  soared to new highs after the federal district court judge in the U.S. vs Google case released a seemingly limited set of remedies to mitigate the tech giant’s monopoly around internet search.  Among his rulings, U.S. District Judge Amit Mehta said on Tuesday that the search giant wouldn’t have to sell its Chrome web browser.  In a closely watched part of the case, Google also won’t be barred from paying Apple to make Google the default search provider on its devices.

headline: Impact of US judge's ruling on Google's search dominance
summary: Google has escaped a breakup of its Chrome browser in a major US competition case, but the judge imposed remedies whose impact remains uncertain just as AI starts to compete with search engines.Judge Amit Mehta, who found a year ago that Google illegally maintained monopolies in online search, did not order the company to sell off its widely-used Chrome browser in his Tuesday ruling.

raw.headline: Impact of US judge's ruling on Google's search dominance
raw.summary: Google has escaped a breakup of its Chrome browser in a major US competition case, but the judge imposed remedies whose impact remains uncertain just as AI starts to compete with search engines.Judge Amit Mehta, who found a year ago that Google illegally maintained monopolies in online search, did not order the company to sell off its widely-used Chrome browser in his Tuesday ruling.

headline: Salesforce’s Struggling Stock Needs Earnings to Show AI Progress
summary: Salesforce shares are down 23% this year, putting them among the 30 worst-performing stocks in the S&P 500 Index.  The plunge has been particularly dramatic in light of the strong showings by software giants like Microsoft Corp., Oracle Corp., and Palantir Technologies Inc., all of whom are considered to be stronger in AI.  While Salesforce, which makes customer relationship management software, has its own AI products, concerns about its long-term trajectory mean the shares may languish even if the company posts strong earnings when it reports after the bell on Wednesday.

headline: Google's AI rivals get a boost from data-sharing order, but tech giant far from routed
summary: SAN FRANCISCO (Reuters) -A rising group of artificial intelligence companies stand to gain from an antitrust ruling on Tuesday that ordered Alphabet's Google to share its invaluable search data with competitors.  Matching Google's heft, though, will take time and huge resources, with no guarantees that any rival product will win as many users, experts said.  While Google was spared the devastating outcome of having to sell its popular Chrome browser and Android operating system, U.S. District Judge Amit Mehta's ruling was a nod to regulators' efforts to level the playing field for companies who have invested billions to boost their AI business.

While Google was spared the devastating outcome of having to sell its popular Chrome browser and Android operating system, U.S. District Judge Amit Mehta's ruling was a nod to regulators' efforts to level the playing field for companies who have invested billions to boost their AI business.

headline: These Stocks Are Moving the Most Today: Alphabet, Apple, Zscaler, Nvidia, Figma, and More
summary: Alphabet  jumped 5.8% after a judge in the U.S. vs. Google antitrust case ruled the search giant wouldn’t have to sell its Chrome web browser.  U.S. District Judge Amit Mehta ruled, however, that Google would no longer be permitted to enter or keep any exclusive contracts that relate to distribution of Google Search, Chrome, Google Assistant, and the Gemini app.  The judge also ordered Google to share search data with its competitors.

headline: Google’s Big Win Is Even Bigger for Apple
summary: A court ruling keeps the search giant intact while also allowing payments to the iPhone maker to continue at a vulnerable time.

raw.headline: Google’s Big Win Is Even Bigger for Apple
raw.summary: A court ruling keeps the search giant intact while also allowing payments to the iPhone maker to continue at a vulnerable time.

headline: Alphabet Stock Jumps After Judge Issues Limited Remedies in Google Monopoly Case
summary: Shares of Google-parent  Alphabet  jumped after the federal district court judge in the U.S. vs Google case released a seemingly limited set of remedies to mitigate the tech giant’s monopoly around internet search.  Among his rulings, U.S. District Judge Amit Mehta said on Tuesday that the search giant wouldn’t have to sell its Chrome web browser.  In a closely watched part of the case, Google also won’t be barred from paying  Apple  to make Google the default search provider on its devices.

raw.headline: Alphabet Stock Jumps After Judge Issues Limited Remedies in Google Monopoly Case

In a closely watched part of the case, Google also won’t be barred from paying  Apple  to make Google the default search provider on its devices.

headline: Apple Koregaon Park opens to customers this Thursday, September 4, in Pune
summary: PUNE, India, September 03, 2025--Apple® today previewed Apple Koregaon Park, its first retail store in Pune and its fourth in India. Located in the heart of a major center of culture and learning, the new store invites customers to discover and shop Apple’s full lineup of products, access personalized service and expert support, and learn how to get even more out of their devices with Today at Apple® sessions.

headline: Stock market today: Nasdaq, S&P 500 futures rise after Google spared in antitrust ruling, with jobs data ahead
summary: US stock futures mostly rose after a ruling in a landmark antitrust case refrained from forcing Google to sell its Chrome browser but instituted other requirements that could shake the tech giant's hold on search.
